manynet 0.2.5
  • Function Overview
  • News

Reference

Making

Functions for constructing, simulating, and importing directed and undirected, one-mode and two-mode networks into whichever class of object is desired for further analysis.

create_empty() create_filled() create_ring() create_star() create_tree() create_lattice() create_components() create_core() create_explicit()

Make networks with defined structures

generate_random() generate_smallworld() generate_scalefree() generate_permutation() generate_utilities()

Make networks with a stochastic element

read_matrix() write_matrix() read_edgelist() write_edgelist() read_nodelist() write_nodelist() read_pajek() write_pajek() read_ucinet() write_ucinet() read_dynetml()

Make networks from/to external formats

as_edgelist() as_matrix() as_igraph() as_tidygraph() as_network() as_siena() as_graphAM()

Making networks into other classes

Manipulating

Functions for manipulating networks into useful formats. This includes functions for reformatting networks into networks of the same dimensions but a different type, e.g. from directed to undirected. It also includes functions for transforming networks into networks with other dimensions, such as from a two-mode network into a one-mode network. There are also functions for splitting networks, e.g. into a list of ego networks, and rejoining them from such lists. There are also tidy-style and igraph-style functions for adding or joining new data on nodes or ties to networks.

to_uniplex() to_undirected() to_directed() to_redirected() to_reciprocated() to_acyclic() to_unweighted() to_unsigned() to_unnamed() to_named() to_simplex() to_onemode() to_multilevel() to_twomode()

Tools for reformatting networks, graphs, and matrices

to_egos() to_subgraphs() to_components() to_waves() to_slices()

Tools for splitting networks, graphs, and matrices into lists

to_mode1() to_mode2() to_giant() to_subgraph() to_ties() to_blocks() to_matching() to_eulerian() to_anti() to_no_isolates() to_galois()

Tools for transforming networks, graphs, and matrices

from_subgraphs() from_egos() from_waves() from_slices()

Tools for joining lists of networks, graphs, and matrices

na_to_zero() na_to_mean()

Tools for imputing missing tie data

add_nodes() delete_nodes() add_ties() add_node_attribute() add_tie_attribute()

Adding nodes and ties and their attributes

join_nodes() join_ties() mutate_ties() select_ties() filter_ties() rename_ties() summarise_ties() bind_node_attributes()

Tidy manipulations of node or tie data

Mapping

Functions for informatively describing networks. This includes identifying properties of networks, nodes, or ties as well as plotting and visualising graphs of different types. The is_*() family all return logical scalars (TRUE or FALSE). network_ measures return one or, in some cases of two-mode measures, two values. All node_ and tie_ measures return a single vector, the length of the nodes or ties in the network, respectively. autographr() graphs any manynet-compatible class object automagically. autographs() and autographd() do the same for multiple networks and dynamic networks, respectively.

is_manynet() is_graph() is_edgelist() is_twomode() is_weighted() is_directed() is_labelled() is_signed() is_complex() is_multiplex() is_uniplex() is_longitudinal() is_dynamic() is_connected() is_perfect_matching() is_eulerian() is_acyclic() is_aperiodic()

Describing network formats

network_nodes() network_ties() network_dims() network_node_attributes() network_tie_attributes()

Describing network properties

node_names() node_mode() node_attribute() tie_attribute() tie_weights() tie_signs()

Describing attributes of nodes or ties in a network

autographr() autographs() autographd()

Quickly graph networks with sensible defaults

layout_tbl_graph_hierarchy() layout_tbl_graph_alluvial() layout_tbl_graph_railway() layout_tbl_graph_ladder() layout_tbl_graph_concentric()

Layout algorithms based on bi- or other partitions

theme_iheid()

Theming ggraph

Data

The package contains a variety of networks useful for pedagogical purposes and used in the course ‘Social Networks Theories and Methods’ and other workshops. Each page documents the source of the data and its format. References are provided for further reading and citation.

ison_adolescents

One-mode subset of the adolescent society network (Coleman 1961)

ison_algebra

Multiplex graph object of friends, social, and task ties (McFarland 2001)

ison_brandes

One-mode and two-mode centrality demonstration networks

ison_karateka

One-mode karateka network (Zachary 1977)

ison_konigsberg

One-mode Seven Bridges of Konigsberg network (Euler 1741)

ison_laterals

Two-mode projection examples (Hollway 2021)

ison_lawfirm

One-mode lawfirm (Lazega 2001)

ison_lotr

One-mode network of Lord of the Rings character interactions

ison_marvel_teams ison_marvel_relationships

Multilevel two-mode affiliation, signed one-mode networks of Marvel comic book characters (Yüksel 2017)

ison_networkers

One-mode EIES dataset (Freeman and Freeman 1979)

ison_southern_women

Two-mode southern women (Davis, Gardner and Gardner 1941)

Tutorials

Functions for loading and extracting code from tutorials.

extract_tute()

Extract code from tutorials

run_tute()

Open tutorials
